results.notes:
Growing in needle litter near Pinus strobus and Tsuga canadensis. Fagus grandifolia and Quercus sp. also present in the area. Context whitish and fleshy. Odor curry-like. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae, some inflated. Spores hyaline, even in outline and echinulate. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (4.5) 4.6 – 5.8 (5.9) × (3.5) 3.7 – 4.8 (5.2) µm, Q = (1) 1.1 – 1.5 (1.6); N = 20, Me = 5.1 × 4.1 µm; Qe = 1.2
Individual spores: 5.75 × 3.64 µm, 4.69 × 4.28 µm, 5.88 × 3.76 µm, 4.80 × 3.92 µm, 4.62 × 3.95 µm, 4.63 × 3.78 µm, 4.86 × 3.86 µm, 5.15 × 3.77 µm, 4.49 × 4.02 µm, 4.80 × 3.51 µm, 5.19 × 3.72 µm, 4.92 × 4.88 µm, 5.53 × 4.74 µm, 4.98 × 4.38 µm, 5.81 × 3.86 µm, 4.48 × 3.88 µm, 4.87 × 4.12 µm, 5.81 × 5.19 µm, 4.98 × 4.84 µm, 5.32 × 4.63 µm

results.notes:
Growing among moss near Ostrya virginiana, Quercus spp., Carya spp. and Fagus grandifolia. May have overlooked small ECM hardwoods. Partially resupinate and covering nearby moss. results.notes:
Another and likely the last example of this taxon from this particular location in WSF. This one was growing in grass under scrub oak and pitch pine at some distance away from obs 288112 (walking 25 yards to the NW and 15 yards to the NE). While ostensibly it could be the progeny of a different mycelium, there’s been some logging in the area over the years, meaning that at one point in time the space was populated by the uninterrupted wooded continuum.
The specimen featured a gorgeous golden yellow pore surface (à la Butyriboletus or Aureoboletus) and some serious yellow rhizomorphs attached to the stipe base. I didn’t bother to look for sclerotia in the tick & chigger infested undergrowth. :-)

results.notes: Growing in hardwood leaf litter in mixed hardwood/conifer forest. Growing in small clusters, with abundant mycelia attached to rotting leaves. Caps 1.5-2.5 cm reddish brown to light tan or buff. KOH negative on cap. Gills cream colored, adnexed to nearly free. Close but not crowded. Stems 2-4 cm long x 2-5 mm thick, tough, hollow at maturity. Brownish but covered with white fuzz, especially at the base, where the mycelia form a cottony mass. Very few narrolwy cylindrical cheilocystidia. Spores inamyloid, tear-drop shaped, 6.6-8.1 × 3-3.8.

results.notes:
Looking to the first photo (after the thumbnail) one can see a ugly piece of calcareous stone with somewhat ugly and bad defined lichens on it. However, it has an incredible and unexpected richeness. Already known to exist there are: (at least) two species of Caloplaca, one species of Opegrapha and one species of Lecania. What else can one expect?

This observation is devoted to the Opegrapha with mini-mini apothecia that we can see as black dots in the second photo. These apothecia are so small that it is impossible to me to make an apothecial section. Apart from this the microscopy is clear:
- one can see pieces of the carbonized exciple,
- asci elongated with 8 spores inside,
- the apical ring of Opegrapha-type, with the ocular chamber and the amyloid ring structure in tholus,
- spores halonate, 3-septate with thickned septa,
- older spores becoming dark brown.
The apothecia of the Opegrapha were confining with a Caloplaca and when I start the microscopy, I found in the preparation some lemon-shaped spore of a Caloplaca. Therefore, I thought that the Opegrapha could be a parasite of the Caloplaca. Following this clue, I was sent to the paper in the reference, where two Opegrapha spp. living on Caloplaca were described, living one of them – Opegrapha hellespontica – lichenicolous in the thallus of Caloplaca aurantia (one of the two species with lemon shaped spores, the other is C. flavescens). But, the problem is that I can see no evidence of a Caloplaca aurantia in the photos.

results.notes:
This bears a lot of visual similarities to Observation 321391 because the red on the stipe is formed in spots instead of the far more typical streaks. It differed because the stipe and pores bruised less willingly, this specimen has a great deal more red in the stipe, and only one specimen was found (under oak and in the woods rather than one of the mown fields nearby) rather than large clumps of them.

These are a typical bolete when it comes to texture, odor, taste, and heft. This specimen was just beginning to get marshmallowy.

No particular odor or taste was noted.

Found in leaf remains between oak trees about 10-20 feet into the woods alongside a mowed clearing. The weather has been quite rainy but the ground underfoot was not wet. We are in the midst of an autumnal flush of spring/summer boletes, and on this same day I found T. alboater and quantities of plumbeoviolaceus, B. variipes and (under spruce) chippewaensis/edulis, Aur. innixus, vermiculosoides and subvelutipes, plus other common species. Also some Hen of the Woods that are more appropriate to the time of year.

Mycelium was white.

Cap flesh was yellow in the stipe and a yellow pale enough to approach white in the caps. Larval tunnels were dark red. The flesh did not turn blue in any notable way.

Thin pore layer was yellow, bruised blue/black after about 10 seconds, and maintained the dark color several hours later. The stipe also bruised greenish/blue but the cap did not. This particular specimen did not bruise readily on any surface.

No chemical tests.
results.location_name: North Park, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
This impressively-sized youngish specimen was brought in for identification to NJMA’s Fungus Fest at the FA. I don’t know where it came from, but it was likely from NJ. It could have been collected the day before.
The mushroom is 20 cm (8") tall. The hemispherical cap is 9 cm wide (the diameter of the circle circumscribed by the margin) and 2 cm thick above the stipe. The tubes are 1.8 cm deep max. The stipe is 18 cm long, 2.8 cm wide at the flaring apex, narrowing to 1.6 cm midway and expanding to 1.9 cm in the base.

results.notes:
These were brought in by a NJMA member (Sara M.) to the club’s Fungus Fest at the Frelinghuysen Arboretum on Sep. 23. They were collected the day before in a small, isolated stand of white pines (5-6 trees), but there could have been a spruce or two mixed in. I have the geocoordinates of this collection, but naturally cannot display them on MO. Sara’s in situ photos of young basidiomata (not posted here) show the cap color is cream to pale tan, similar to the cap colors seen in my images.
The mushrooms are up to 12 cm tall. The caps are 7-9.5 cm wide. The tubes are 7-12 mm deep. The stipes are equal to sub-ventricose, 2-2.5 wide at the apex and slightly narrower below. The odor is very pleasant; the taste of raw flesh is sweet and nutty. Note the pale magenta line in the cut flesh right above the tubes.

results.notes:
Found growing on a wooded ridge near mature white pine. Mature shagbark hickory also close; smallish oaks in the vicinity. All trees are native/natural (none planted).

Cap surface radially streaked with green along ~50% of the outer portion, and quite dark on the disc. This seemed too dark to me. But one specimen seen at Amanita Studies (found in NJ) shows a cap with very similar color.

Got a very meager spore print. Application of Meltzer’s was initially inconclusive, as I did not perceive darkening on the faint print. Viewed at 400x, the spores appeared to be amyloid. To increase my level of confidence I performed a step suggested by Dr. Tulloss. Smash mounted gill material in Meltzer’s and observed the contrast in darkness between the basidia and the spores. (This really is a nice trick!)

Spores subglobose to broadly ellipsoid, but a bit smaller than the reported dimensions for phalloides. My estimate here is 7-8 × 6-6.5.

Habitat is seen in the last 4 photos. The “10 foot tall” unidentified conifer is perhaps a type of spruce. This small tree is >40 feet from where the mushroom fruited (I stepped it off). Between this smallish conifer and the area between the large white pines (where the mushroom grew) there are young white pines and small oaks (some type of red oak). Possibly also a few small birch, aspen, or maple in the area.

Two weeks later I found and collected obs 349697 from the same exact spot (within a 4 foot radius).

Now this observation bears some explanation. This looks to me like a large shelf which became is quite old (perhaps from early Summer or even Spring) and has been covered by a mold fungi. I say this, because the mold appears to cover the entire surface including the top of the shelf. The surface should be the same on the top and bottom. Also the color is the same all around as well. This shelf appears to be something that has appeared yearly since beneath the current one are two large black shapes that I’m certain are decayed shelves. The last photo is of a cross-section of the newest shelf and the photo before it of one of the old shelves.

results.notes:
Collected by J. M. Barg of NJMA in beech & oak woods on a private property somewhere along McGuire Access Hwy and displayed at NJMA’s mushroom fair in Morristown the next day. The location is in the Pine Barrens area, but the presence of beech suggests a different type of habitat settings.
Larger fruitbody dimensions: Overall height = 5.5 cm; Cap = 5 cm wide, 1.3 cm thick above the stipe; Tubes = 7 mm deep; Stipe = 4 cm long, 1.4 cm thick at apex, 1.7 cm thick at the widest point in lower half.
This collection ostensibly looks like a Hemileccinum sp., but that’s arguable. It could very well be B-R-B/BENA’s UB-5, which is represented on MO by Walter Sturgeon’s 6 collections from 3 different sites in OH (advanced search = “Hemileccinum + Mycowalt”). Another possibility is the cryptic bolete reported a number of times from Louisiana by Logan Wiedenfeld – e.g., obs 248795 – which may or may not be the same as UB-5. At any rate, this is the first reported collection of this kind from NJ. Will likely be scheduling it for sequencing in a foreseeable future.

notes_fields.Habitat: Growing in soil in leaf litter in mixed hardwood forest.
notes_fields.Cap/upper_surface: Up to 10-cm diameter; multi-lobed; fleshy (easily cut) becoming more corky with age. Smooth; bald; no scales. Color changing from tan brown with white margin when young; to brown center fading to white at margin, and finally to deep red-brown to dark brown with tan-to-white margin.
notes_fields.Cap/underside: Grey teeth running down the stipe; ‘bumps’ when young, becoming up to 4mm in length at maturity.
notes_fields.Stipe: Central; 3-4 cm long, ca. 1 cm at apex remaining approximately equal along its length or becoming wider towards the base base
notes_fields.Chemistry: Flesh stained immediately green with KOH (3%), and darkening to black immediately. Dilution showed that the ‘black’ was concentrated green stain.

results.notes:
After sifting through J. M. Barg’s large box of fungi collected from the beech & oak woods on a private property somewhere along McGuire Access Hwy he brought to NJMA’s mushroom fair in Morristown the next day, I fished out these three fruiting bodies of what appears to be sclerotiorum, or a related taxon. These come in addition to obs 336043, also from the same location. I don’t know if all 4 sporocaps were growing next to each other, but the two smaller ones seen here clearly came from the same spot because they have moss stuck to their stipes. The location is in the general Pine Barrens area, but the presence of beech (intolerant of sandy acidic soil) suggests a different type of environment.
Just like 336043, this collection is characterized by the unusually dark and dense red-punctate pattern on the stipe that I haven’t associated with any of my previous collections of sclerotiorum (confirmed or purported) or its genetically distinct lookalike I dubbed “pseudosclerotiorum” (215764 & 286328). Note the variably-colored pulvinate caps and their heavily inrolled margins, the red-tinged cap flesh, and the variable bluing action of the exposed context.
Larger fb = voucher A; 2 smaller fbs = voucher B.

results.notes:
Collected at 6,100 feet under mix conifers, mostly spruce.
Seems like these could be a specie in between T. caligatum and T. murrillianum (T. magnivelare):
Is not very brown or scaly. Smells good, spicy, but subtle. Tastes good, is not bitter.
Cap size around 9 cm, stem dia. about 3.75 cm, length 9 cm, tapered down to a hard tip. Above the veil the stalk is white, and with some reddish brown scales below. Crowded gills staining reddish brown, covered by the veil initially, and then making a large cottony ring. Spores 5.8 – 6.8 x 3.8 – 4.15
